Holmes leaned forward in his chair, his keen eyes fixed upon me with that penetrating gaze which I had come to know so well. "You say you saw her in conversation with her maid, Watson? Pray, continue. The smallest detail may prove of the utmost importance."

I nodded, recalling the scene with perfect clarity. "It was yesterday evening, just as the sun was setting. I had taken a stroll through Hyde Park, as is my habit, when I observed Lady Beatrice standing near the Serpentine. She was speaking with her maid—a young woman with dark hair, rather plainly dressed. There was an intensity in their exchange that struck me as unusual."

"Unusual in what way?" Holmes inquired, steepling his fingers beneath his chin.

"Well," I replied, "one does not often see a lady of her station engaged in such earnest conversation with a servant. They stood close together, speaking in low tones, and Lady Beatrice appeared agitated. At one point, she even grasped the maid’s arm, as if to emphasize some point."

Holmes's eyes gleamed with interest. "Did you overhear any part of their discussion?"

"Only a fragment. As I passed by, I caught the maid saying, 'But madam, it is too dangerous.' Lady Beatrice replied, 'I have no choice. It must be done tonight.' Then they noticed my approach and fell silent."

"A most suggestive exchange," murmured Holmes. He rose from his chair and began to pace the room, his hands clasped behind his back. "Watson, you have done well to bring this to my attention. Lady Beatrice’s behavior has been a puzzle to me for some days, and this may provide the missing piece."

I could not suppress a smile. "You suspect foul play, then?"

"Foul play? No, Watson, not necessarily. But I do suspect that Lady Beatrice is entangled in some scheme—one that she believes she cannot escape. The involvement of her maid suggests a domestic dimension to the affair, which is often the most treacherous kind."

He paused by the window, staring out at the bustling streets of London. "Tell me, did you notice anything else about the maid? Any distinguishing features?"

I searched my memory. "She wore a locket—a silver one, I think. It caught the light as she turned her head."

Holmes whirled around, his face alight with sudden understanding. "A silver locket! Watson, you are a marvel! That detail may be the key to everything."

Before I could inquire further, he had seized his hat and coat from the stand. "Come, Watson, there is no time to lose. We must pay a visit to Lady Beatrice at once."

"But Holmes," I protested, "surely it would be more prudent to gather more information before confronting her?"

"Ordinarily, yes," he admitted, flinging open the door. "But if my suspicions are correct, Lady Beatrice is in grave danger. Every moment we delay increases the risk."

With that, he was out the door and down the stairs, leaving me to hurry after him, my mind racing with unanswered questions. What had Holmes deduced from so few clues? And what peril could possibly threaten a woman of Lady Beatrice’s standing?

As we hailed a cab and sped through the streets, Holmes remained silent, his brow furrowed in thought. At last, as we neared our destination, he turned to me. "Watson, when we arrive, I must ask you to follow my lead without question. The situation is delicate, and a misstep could prove disastrous."

"Of course," I agreed, though my curiosity burned within me.

The cab drew up before Lady Beatrice’s elegant townhouse, and we were admitted by a solemn-faced butler. Holmes wasted no time. "Is Lady Beatrice at home? We must speak with her at once."

The butler hesitated. "I am afraid her ladyship is not receiving visitors—"

Holmes cut him off. "This is a matter of life and death. Inform her that Sherlock Holmes insists upon seeing her immediately."

The butler’s eyes widened slightly at the name, and with a curt nod, he disappeared into the house. Moments later, he returned, ushering us into a lavishly furnished drawing room where Lady Beatrice awaited us.

She was a striking woman, tall and regal, with an air of quiet dignity. But her composure seemed strained, and her hands trembled slightly as she greeted us. "Mr. Holmes, Dr. Watson, to what do I owe this unexpected visit?"

Holmes wasted no time on pleasantries. "My lady, I must speak plainly. You are in danger, and I believe your maid is involved."

Lady Beatrice paled. "I—I do not know what you mean."

"Watson here observed you in conversation with her yesterday," Holmes pressed. "You spoke of something that must be done tonight—something dangerous. And your maid wears a silver locket, does she not?"

Her breath caught. "How could you know that?"

"Because that locket is the symbol of a notorious blackmailing ring," Holmes declared. "They prey upon women of your station, using their servants as spies to gather compromising information. Your maid is not loyal to you—she is their agent."

Lady Beatrice sank into a chair, her face a mask of despair. "Then it is as I feared. She has been threatening to expose a—a private matter unless I pay her a sum I cannot possibly afford."

Holmes’s expression softened. "You are not alone in this, my lady. I have dealt with this ring before. If you will trust me, I can put an end to their schemes."

Tears welled in her eyes. "Oh, Mr. Holmes, if only you could!"

"Then let us act swiftly," he said. "Where is your maid now?"

"She is upstairs, in her room. She believes I am preparing the money for her."

Holmes turned to me. "Watson, remain here with Lady Beatrice. I shall deal with the maid."

With that, he strode from the room, leaving me to comfort the distraught noblewoman. Within minutes, we heard a commotion upstairs—a cry of surprise, then silence. Then Holmes reappeared, his face grim but satisfied.

"It is done," he announced. "The maid has been taken into custody, and the blackmailers’ operation will soon be dismantled. You are safe, Lady Beatrice."

She clasped his hand in gratitude. "I cannot thank you enough, Mr. Holmes. You have saved me from ruin."

Holmes bowed slightly. "It is my duty, my lady. Now, if you will excuse us, Watson and I must see this matter through to its conclusion."

As we left the house, I marveled once more at my friend’s brilliance. "Holmes, how did you deduce the maid’s involvement so quickly?"

He smiled faintly. "The locket was the clue, Watson. I recognized it from a previous case. These blackmailers are nothing if not consistent in their methods."

I shook my head in admiration. "You never cease to amaze me."

"All in a day’s work, my dear fellow," he replied, as we hailed another cab and vanished into the London night.

events.title: Holmes Claims Solution; Lestrade Presents Conflicting Evidence
detailed_summary: As Lord St. Simon prepares to leave, Holmes startles him by declaring, "I have solved it."
St. Simon departs, skeptical that Holmes can locate his wife.
Holmes expresses amusement at St. Simon's attitude and remarks to Watson that he had already formed his conclusions before the client even arrived, based on similar past cases.
Inspector Lestrade arrives, looking wet and dissatisfied.
Lestrade complains about the baffling nature of the St. Simon case, stating he can make no sense of it.
Holmes notes Lestrade's wet clothes; Lestrade reveals he has been dragging the Serpentine lake in search of Lady St. Simon's body.
Holmes laughs heartily, suggesting Lestrade would have equal luck searching the Trafalgar Square fountain.
Lestrade, annoyed, challenges Holmes, who asserts his mind is made up despite only just hearing the facts.
Lestrade dismisses Holmes's confidence and produces a water-soaked wedding dress, shoes, wreath, veil, and ring, found floating in the Serpentine, identified as belonging to the bride.
He presents this discovery as a challenge to Holmes.

“Should you be fortunate enough to solve this problem,” said our client, rising.
“I have solved it.”
“Eh? What was that?”
“I say that I have solved it.”
“Where, then, is my wife?”
“That is a detail which I shall speedily supply.”
Lord St. Simon shook his head. “I am afraid that it will take wiser heads than yours or mine,” he remarked, and bowing in a stately, old-fashioned manner he departed.
“It is very good of Lord St. Simon to honour my head by putting it on a level with his own,” said Sherlock Holmes, laughing. “I think that I shall have a whisky and soda and a cigar after all this cross-questioning. I had formed my conclusions as to the case before our client came into the room.”
“My dear Holmes!”
“I have notes of several similar cases, though none, as I remarked before, which were quite as prompt. My whole examination served to turn my conjecture into a certainty. Circumstantial evidence is occasionally very convincing, as when you find a trout in the milk, to quote Thoreau’s example.”
“But I have heard all that you have heard.”
“Without, however, the knowledge of pre-existing cases which serves me so well. There was a parallel instance in Aberdeen some years back, and something on very much the same lines at Munich the year after the Franco-Prussian War. It is one of these cases—but, hullo, here is Lestrade! Good-afternoon, Lestrade! You will find an extra tumbler upon the sideboard, and there are cigars in the box.”
The official detective was attired in a pea-jacket and cravat, which gave him a decidedly nautical appearance, and he carried a black canvas bag in his hand. With a short greeting he seated himself and lit the cigar which had been offered to him.
“What’s up, then?” asked Holmes with a twinkle in his eye. “You look dissatisfied.”
“And I feel dissatisfied. It is this infernal St. Simon marriage case. I can make neither head nor tail of the business.”
“Really! You surprise me.”
“Who ever heard of such a mixed affair? Every clue seems to slip through my fingers. I have been at work upon it all day.”
“And very wet it seems to have made you,” said Holmes laying his hand upon the arm of the pea-jacket.
“Yes, I have been dragging the Serpentine.”
“In Heaven’s name, what for?”
“In search of the body of Lady St. Simon.”
Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair and laughed heartily.
“Have you dragged the basin of Trafalgar Square fountain?” he asked.
“Why? What do you mean?”
“Because you have just as good a chance of finding this lady in the one as in the other.”
Lestrade shot an angry glance at my companion. “I suppose you know all about it,” he snarled.
“Well, I have only just heard the facts, but my mind is made up.”
“Oh, indeed! Then you think that the Serpentine plays no part in the matter?”
“I think it very unlikely.”
“Then perhaps you will kindly explain how it is that we found this in it?” He opened his bag as he spoke, and tumbled onto the floor a wedding-dress of watered silk, a pair of white satin shoes and a bride’s wreath and veil, all discoloured and soaked in water. “There,” said he, putting a new wedding-ring upon the top of the pile. “There is a little nut for you to crack, Master Holmes.”

“Should you be fortunate enough to solve this problem,” said our client, rising, “I shall be eternally in your debt, Mr. Holmes. The matter weighs heavily upon me, and I confess I see no way forward without your assistance.”  

Sherlock Holmes leaned back in his chair, his fingers steepled beneath his chin, his keen grey eyes fixed upon our visitor with that penetrating gaze which so often seemed to pierce through the very soul of a man. “You have presented the facts clearly, Mr. Blackwood,” he remarked. “Yet there are one or two points which require further elucidation before I can venture an opinion.”  

Our client, a tall, gaunt man of perhaps forty years, with the bearing of one accustomed to command, hesitated at the door. “I have told you all I know,” he said, his voice strained with anxiety. “If there is anything else—”  

“The time, for instance,” Holmes interrupted. “You mentioned that the incident occurred shortly after midnight, yet your own movements during that hour remain somewhat vague. Might I ask where you were at that precise moment?”  

A shadow passed over Blackwood’s face. “I was in my study, attending to correspondence. My valet can vouch for my presence there.”  

“Ah, the valet,” murmured Holmes. “A most convenient witness. And yet, I wonder…” His voice trailed off, leaving the suggestion hanging in the air like the smoke from his pipe.  

I could see our client stiffen. “Mr. Holmes, if you imply—”  

“I imply nothing,” Holmes said smoothly. “I merely observe. It is my habit to examine every detail, however trivial it may seem. You may rest assured that I shall give your case my fullest attention.”  

With a curt nod, Blackwood took his leave, and the sound of his footsteps echoed down the staircase before fading into the hum of Baker Street.  

“Well, Watson,” said Holmes, turning to me with a spark of amusement in his eyes, “what do you make of our Mr. Blackwood?”  

I considered the matter carefully. “He seemed a man of substance, undoubtedly troubled by his predicament. His story was consistent, though I confess I found his manner somewhat guarded.”  

“Guarded indeed!” Holmes exclaimed. “And with excellent reason. Did you note the slight tremor in his left hand when he mentioned the valet? The unconscious tightening of his jaw at the question of his whereabouts? Our client is concealing something, Watson—something of considerable importance.”  

“But if he seeks your help, why not disclose the full truth?”  

“Because men in his position seldom do,” Holmes replied, reaching for his violin. “Pride, fear, shame—these are powerful motivators for silence. Yet the truth has a way of revealing itself, often in the most unexpected fashion.” He drew the bow across the strings, producing a low, thoughtful note. “I fancy a visit to Blackwood’s residence may prove illuminating. Would you care to accompany me?”  

“Certainly,” I said, reaching for my hat. “But what do you expect to find?”  

Holmes’s lips curved into that enigmatic smile I knew so well. “The missing piece of the puzzle, my dear Watson. And when we have it, this little mystery will unravel with satisfying swiftness.”  

And with that, we stepped out into the bustling streets of London, where danger and intrigue lurked in every shadow, and where the game—as Holmes so often declared—was forever afoot.

“Oh, indeed!” said my friend, blowing blue rings into the air. “You dragged them from the Serpentine?”
“No. They were found floating near the margin by a park-keeper. They have been identified as her clothes, and it seemed to me that if the clothes were there the body would not be far off.”
“By the same brilliant reasoning, every man’s body is to be found in the neighbourhood of his wardrobe. And pray what did you hope to arrive at through this?”
“At some evidence implicating Flora Millar in the disappearance.”
“I am afraid that you will find it difficult.”
“Are you, indeed, now?” cried Lestrade with some bitterness. “I am afraid, Holmes, that you are not very practical with your deductions and your inferences. You have made two blunders in as many minutes. This dress does implicate Miss Flora Millar.”
“And how?”
“In the dress is a pocket. In the pocket is a card-case. In the card-case is a note. And here is the very note.” He slapped it down upon the table in front of him. “Listen to this: ‘You will see me when all is ready. Come at once. F. H. M.’ Now my theory all along has been that Lady St. Simon was decoyed away by Flora Millar, and that she, with confederates, no doubt, was responsible for her disappearance. Here, signed with her initials, is the very note which was no doubt quietly slipped into her hand at the door and which lured her within their reach.”
“Very good, Lestrade,” said Holmes, laughing. “You really are very fine indeed. Let me see it.” He took up the paper in a listless way, but his attention instantly became riveted, and he gave a little cry of satisfaction. “This is indeed important,” said he.
“Ha! you find it so?”
“Extremely so. I congratulate you warmly.”
Lestrade rose in his triumph and bent his head to look. “Why,” he shrieked, “you’re looking at the wrong side!”
“On the contrary, this is the right side.”
“The right side? You’re mad! Here is the note written in pencil over here.”
“And over here is what appears to be the fragment of a hotel bill, which interests me deeply.”
“There’s nothing in it. I looked at it before,” said Lestrade. “‘Oct. 4th, rooms 8s., breakfast 2s. 6d., cocktail 1s., lunch 2s. 6d., glass sherry, 8d.’ I see nothing in that.”
“Very likely not. It is most important, all the same. As to the note, it is important also, or at least the initials are, so I congratulate you again.”
“I’ve wasted time enough,” said Lestrade, rising. “I believe in hard work and not in sitting by the fire spinning fine theories. Good-day, Mr. Holmes, and we shall see which gets to the bottom of the matter first.” He gathered up the garments, thrust them into the bag, and made for the door.

“Oh, indeed!” said my friend, blowing blue rings into the air. “But surely the body was not dragged up by the clothes?”  

“No, sir, but the clothes were found floating.”  

“That is very singular.”  

“Well, sir, it is not more singular than that a man’s body should be found floating with his clothes.”  

“You think, then, that the clothes were thrown in after the body?”  

“I do, sir.”  

“That is possible. But it is also possible that the clothes were thrown in without the body. That is the point.”  

Lestrade looked at Holmes as if he thought him mad.  

“Well, sir,” he said, “I suppose that is possible, but I don’t quite see the object of it.”  

“To deceive, of course.”  

“But why should anyone wish to deceive us by throwing the clothes in?”  

“That is what we have to find out. You think, then, Lestrade, that the clothes were thrown in after the body?”  

“I do, sir.”  

“And that the body was thrown in from the bridge?”  

“Yes, sir.”  

“Then the clothes were thrown in from the bridge also?”  

“Undoubtedly.”  

“Dear me! That is really very interesting. Now, what was found in the pockets?”  

“Only a card-case with a note in it.”  

“Ah! That is indeed important. Let me see it.”  

Lestrade took a small card-case from his pocket and handed it to Holmes. Holmes opened it and took out a folded piece of paper. He examined it carefully.  

“This is very important,” he said. “The initials ‘F. H. M.’ are upon it. Now, Lestrade, what do you make of that?”  

“Flora Millar,” said Lestrade triumphantly.  

“Precisely. And the note?”  

“‘You will see me when all is ready. Come at once. F. H. M.’”  

“Now, Lestrade, what do you deduce from that?”  

“Well, sir, I suppose that Flora Millar wrote the note and that she lured Lady St. Simon away.”  

“Very good, Lestrade,” said Holmes. “You have got it.”  

Lestrade swelled with pride.  

“But, you see,” continued Holmes, “I am looking at the back of the note.”  

“The back of the note?” cried Lestrade. “You are mad, Holmes! There is nothing there.”  

“On the contrary, there is a very important thing—the fragment of a hotel bill. ‘Oct. 4th, rooms 8s., breakfast 2s. 6d., cocktail 1s.,’ etc.”  

“What of it?”  

“Everything, my dear Lestrade. Everything. And the initials ‘F. H. M.’—they are of the greatest importance. I congratulate you.”  

Lestrade got up. “I am afraid that I am wasting your time, Mr. Holmes,” he said. “I believe in hard work, and not in sitting by the fire spinning theories. Good-day, sir, and we shall see who gets to the bottom of the matter first.” He gathered up the garments, thrust them into the bag, and made for the door.  

“Just one word to you, Lestrade,” said Holmes, before the detective vanished, “I will tell you the true solution of the matter. Lady St. Simon is a myth. There is not, and there never has been, any such person.”  

Lestrade looked sadly at my companion. Then he turned to me, tapped his forehead three times, shook his head solemnly, and hurried away.

LLM_completions.prefix-probing:
“Oh, indeed!” said my friend, blowing blue rings into the air. “You must forgive me, Watson, but I find your astonishment rather amusing. The case, as you describe it, presents no extraordinary features—merely a series of deductions so elementary that even you, with your limited grasp of my methods, might have arrived at the same conclusion had you but observed the trifling details.”

I frowned, for though I was accustomed to Holmes’s occasional condescension, his words stung nonetheless. “Then pray enlighten me,” I said, “for I confess I see nothing remarkable in the fact that a man should vanish from his lodgings without a trace.”

Holmes leaned back in his chair, his long fingers steepled beneath his chin. “Consider the facts, Watson. The gentleman in question—Mr. Reginald Musgrave, was it not?—left behind no note, no sign of disturbance, and yet his pipe, his favourite meerschaum, was found cold upon the table. A man does not abandon his pipe so lightly, especially one to which he is so attached. The absence of struggle suggests he left willingly, yet the pipe’s abandonment hints at haste. What, then, could compel a man to depart in such a manner?”

I pondered this for a moment. “A sudden summons, perhaps? A matter of urgency?”

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with satisfaction. “Precisely! And what manner of summons would demand such immediate attention that a man would forsake even his cherished pipe? A telegram, Watson! A message delivered with the swiftness of electricity, bearing tidings so pressing that delay was unthinkable.”

“But why, then, has no such telegram been found?” I objected.

“Because,” Holmes replied, exhaling another languid ring of smoke, “it was not left behind. It was taken—by the same hand that ensured Mr. Musgrave’s disappearance. The telegram was the bait, Watson, and our unfortunate gentleman the prey.”

A chill ran down my spine. “You mean to say he was lured into a trap?”

“I do. And the architect of that trap is none other than the man who stood to gain the most from his absence. Tell me, Watson, who inherits the Musgrave estate should our vanished friend fail to return?”

I gasped. “His cousin—Philip Musgrave! But Holmes, this is mere conjecture. We have no proof!”

“Proof,” said Holmes, rising abruptly and seizing his hat, “is what we shall now seek. Come, Watson! The game is afoot, and I fancy we shall find our answers at the telegraph office.”

With that, he strode toward the door, leaving me to scramble after him, my mind whirling with the implications of his reasoning. As we descended the stairs to Baker Street, I could not help but marvel at the swiftness with which Holmes had unraveled the mystery—or so it seemed. Yet experience had taught me that even his most brilliant deductions were not infallible. 

Would this prove another triumph for the world’s only consulting detective, or had some subtle flaw in his logic escaped even his keen intellect? Only time would tell—and time, as Holmes was fond of remarking, was the one opponent even he could not always outwit.

“Just one hint to you, Lestrade,” drawled Holmes before his rival vanished; “I will tell you the true solution of the matter. Lady St. Simon is a myth. There is not, and there never has been, any such person.”
Lestrade looked sadly at my companion. Then he turned to me, tapped his forehead three times, shook his head solemnly, and hurried away.
He had hardly shut the door behind him when Holmes rose to put on his overcoat. “There is something in what the fellow says about outdoor work,” he remarked, “so I think, Watson, that I must leave you to your papers for a little.”
It was after five o’clock when Sherlock Holmes left me, but I had no time to be lonely, for within an hour there arrived a confectioner’s man with a very large flat box. This he unpacked with the help of a youth whom he had brought with him, and presently, to my very great astonishment, a quite epicurean little cold supper began to be laid out upon our humble lodging-house mahogany. There were a couple of brace of cold woodcock, a pheasant, a pâté de foie gras pie with a group of ancient and cobwebby bottles. Having laid out all these luxuries, my two visitors vanished away, like the genii of the Arabian Nights, with no explanation save that the things had been paid for and were ordered to this address.
Just before nine o’clock Sherlock Holmes stepped briskly into the room. His features were gravely set, but there was a light in his eye which made me think that he had not been disappointed in his conclusions.
“They have laid the supper, then,” he said, rubbing his hands.
“You seem to expect company. They have laid for five.”
“Yes, I fancy we may have some company dropping in,” said he. “I am surprised that Lord St. Simon has not already arrived. Ha! I fancy that I hear his step now upon the stairs.”
It was indeed our visitor of the afternoon who came bustling in, dangling his glasses more vigorously than ever, and with a very perturbed expression upon his aristocratic features.
“My messenger reached you, then?” asked Holmes.
“Yes, and I confess that the contents startled me beyond measure. Have you good authority for what you say?”
“The best possible.”
Lord St. Simon sank into a chair and passed his hand over his forehead.
“What will the Duke say,” he murmured, “when he hears that one of the family has been subjected to such humiliation?”
“It is the purest accident. I cannot allow that there is any humiliation.”
“Ah, you look on these things from another standpoint.”
“I fail to see that anyone is to blame. I can hardly see how the lady could have acted otherwise, though her abrupt method of doing it was undoubtedly to be regretted. Having no mother, she had no one to advise her at such a crisis.”
“It was a slight, sir, a public slight,” said Lord St. Simon, tapping his fingers upon the table.
“You must make allowance for this poor girl, placed in so unprecedented a position.”
“I will make no allowance. I am very angry indeed, and I have been shamefully used.”
“I think that I heard a ring,” said Holmes. “Yes, there are steps on the landing. If I cannot persuade you to take a lenient view of the matter, Lord St. Simon, I have brought an advocate here who may be more successful.” He opened the door and ushered in a lady and gentleman. “Lord St. Simon,” said he “allow me to introduce you to Mr. and Mrs. Francis Hay Moulton. The lady, I think, you have already met.”
At the sight of these newcomers our client had sprung from his seat and stood very erect, with his eyes cast down and his hand thrust into the breast of his frock-coat, a picture of offended dignity. The lady had taken a quick step forward and had held out her hand to him, but he still refused to raise his eyes. It was as well for his resolution, perhaps, for her pleading face was one which it was hard to resist.
“You’re angry, Robert,” said she. “Well, I guess you have every cause to be.”
“Pray make no apology to me,” said Lord St. Simon bitterly.
“Oh, yes, I know that I have treated you real bad and that I should have spoken to you before I went; but I was kind of rattled, and from the time when I saw Frank here again I just didn’t know what I was doing or saying. I only wonder I didn’t fall down and do a faint right there before the altar.”
“Perhaps, Mrs. Moulton, you would like my friend and me to leave the room while you explain this matter?”
“If I may give an opinion,” remarked the strange gentleman, “we’ve had just a little too much secrecy over this business already. For my part, I should like all Europe and America to hear the rights of it.” He was a small, wiry, sunburnt man, clean-shaven, with a sharp face and alert manner.
“Then I’ll tell our story right away,” said the lady. “Frank here and I met in ’84, in McQuire’s camp, near the Rockies, where Pa was working a claim. We were engaged to each other, Frank and I; but then one day father struck a rich pocket and made a pile, while poor Frank here had a claim that petered out and came to nothing. The richer Pa grew the poorer was Frank; so at last Pa wouldn’t hear of our engagement lasting any longer, and he took me away to ’Frisco. Frank wouldn’t throw up his hand, though; so he followed me there, and he saw me without Pa knowing anything about it. It would only have made him mad to know, so we just fixed it all up for ourselves. Frank said that he would go and make his pile, too, and never come back to claim me until he had as much as Pa. So then I promised to wait for him to the end of time and pledged myself not to marry anyone else while he lived. ‘Why shouldn’t we be married right away, then,’ said he, ‘and then I will feel sure of you; and I won’t claim to be your husband until I come back?’ Well, we talked it over, and he had fixed it all up so nicely, with a clergyman all ready in waiting, that we just did it right there; and then Frank went off to seek his fortune, and I went back to Pa.
“The next I heard of Frank was that he was in Montana, and then he went prospecting in Arizona, and then I heard of him from New Mexico. After that came a long newspaper story about how a miners’ camp had been attacked by Apache Indians, and there was my Frank’s name among the killed. I fainted dead away, and I was very sick for months after. Pa thought I had a decline and took me to half the doctors in ’Frisco. Not a word of news came for a year and more, so that I never doubted that Frank was really dead. Then Lord St. Simon came to ’Frisco, and we came to London, and a marriage was arranged, and Pa was very pleased, but I felt all the time that no man on this earth would ever take the place in my heart that had been given to my poor Frank.
“Still, if I had married Lord St. Simon, of course I’d have done my duty by him. We can’t command our love, but we can our actions. I went to the altar with him with the intention to make him just as good a wife as it was in me to be. But you may imagine what I felt when, just as I came to the altar rails, I glanced back and saw Frank standing and looking at me out of the first pew. I thought it was his ghost at first; but when I looked again there he was still, with a kind of question in his eyes, as if to ask me whether I were glad or sorry to see him. I wonder I didn’t drop. I know that everything was turning round, and the words of the clergyman were just like the buzz of a bee in my ear. I didn’t know what to do. Should I stop the service and make a scene in the church? I glanced at him again, and he seemed to know what I was thinking, for he raised his finger to his lips to tell me to be still. Then I saw him scribble on a piece of paper, and I knew that he was writing me a note. As I passed his pew on the way out I dropped my bouquet over to him, and he slipped the note into my hand when he returned me the flowers. It was only a line asking me to join him when he made the sign to me to do so. Of course I never doubted for a moment that my first duty was now to him, and I determined to do just whatever he might direct.
“When I got back I told my maid, who had known him in California, and had always been his friend. I ordered her to say nothing, but to get a few things packed and my ulster ready. I know I ought to have spoken to Lord St. Simon, but it was dreadful hard before his mother and all those great people. I just made up my mind to run away and explain afterwards. I hadn’t been at the table ten minutes before I saw Frank out of the window at the other side of the road. He beckoned to me and then began walking into the Park. I slipped out, put on my things, and followed him. Some woman came talking something or other about Lord St. Simon to me—seemed to me from the little I heard as if he had a little secret of his own before marriage also—but I managed to get away from her and soon overtook Frank. We got into a cab together, and away we drove to some lodgings he had taken in Gordon Square, and that was my true wedding after all those years of waiting. Frank had been a prisoner among the Apaches, had escaped, came on to ’Frisco, found that I had given him up for dead and had gone to England, followed me there, and had come upon me at last on the very morning of my second wedding.”
“I saw it in a paper,” explained the American. “It gave the name and the church but not where the lady lived.”
“Then we had a talk as to what we should do, and Frank was all for openness, but I was so ashamed of it all that I felt as if I should like to vanish away and never see any of them again—just sending a line to Pa, perhaps, to show him that I was alive. It was awful to me to think of all those lords and ladies sitting round that breakfast-table and waiting for me to come back. So Frank took my wedding-clothes and things and made a bundle of them, so that I should not be traced, and dropped them away somewhere where no one could find them. It is likely that we should have gone on to Paris to-morrow, only that this good gentleman, Mr. Holmes, came round to us this evening, though how he found us is more than I can think, and he showed us very clearly and kindly that I was wrong and that Frank was right, and that we should be putting ourselves in the wrong if we were so secret. Then he offered to give us a chance of talking to Lord St. Simon alone, and so we came right away round to his rooms at once. Now, Robert, you have heard it all, and I am very sorry if I have given you pain, and I hope that you do not think very meanly of me.”

And with that Holmes turned upon his heel and made his way into the house, leaving Lestrade staring after him in mute astonishment.  

A few minutes later we were seated in the old sitting-room, where Holmes had already explained to me the main facts of the case.  

"I have been a blind fool, Watson," said he.  

"It was only last night that the truth came home to me. I had been groping about in the dark, when suddenly I saw the light. It is incredible how simple the explanation is."  

"Then you have solved it?"  

"All but the last link, Watson. But I have that in my pocket. You shall hear the whole story before I sleep, and I think you will agree with me that it is one of the most singular that has ever come our way."  

He had hardly spoken when there came the sound of heavy steps in the passage, and a moment later Lord St. Simon burst into the room.  

"Mr. Holmes," he cried, "I have just received a most extraordinary and offensive letter from you. If this is a joke, sir, it is a most questionable one. If it is true, it is an outrage."  

Holmes looked pained.  

"I assure you, Lord St. Simon," said he, "that my letter was written in all sincerity. I should not dream of jesting upon so serious a matter."  

"Serious! Do you call it serious that my wife should be dragged from my house on my wedding-day?"  

"The alternative was that she should be exposed as a bigamist."  

The nobleman started back.  

"What do you mean?" he gasped.  

"I mean that there was no Lady St. Simon, because there was already a Mrs. Francis Hay Moulton."  

"Impossible!"  

"It is the truth. The lady whom you married was the wife of another man."  

"Where is your proof?"  

"Here it is," said Holmes, drawing a paper from his pocket. "This is a copy of the register of the marriage of Hatty Doran to Francis Hay Moulton, in the city of San Francisco, some years ago. The original is in the office of the City Recorder."  

Lord St. Simon glanced at the paper and then at us, his face ashen.  

"Then you mean," he stammered, "that while I thought I was marrying a virgin, I was in reality wedding a married woman?"  

"It is even worse than that," said Holmes. "You were marrying a woman whose husband was still alive."  

"Where is he, then?"  

"He is in London. He arrived yesterday. I have his address."  

The unfortunate nobleman sank into a chair and buried his face in his hands.  

"This is too much," he groaned. "Do you mean to tell me that while I was being married in the church, this man was waiting outside?"  

"It was so."  

"And that she knew it?"  

"She did not know it until she saw him in the church."

Lady St. Simon is not dead, nor has she ever been in any real danger. The entire affair has been a carefully orchestrated deception—one designed to free her from a marriage she never desired.”  

Lestrade halted mid-stride, his face a mask of incredulity. “What on earth are you talking about, Holmes? The lady vanished from the Dorchester Hotel without a trace! Her gloves were found in the Serpentine, her wedding ring discarded—”  

“Precisely,” Holmes interrupted, his eyes gleaming with that familiar, infuriating certainty. “A trail too obvious, too neatly laid. Consider the facts: Lady St. Simon is an American, independent in spirit, and by all accounts, deeply reluctant about this union. Her father, a wealthy businessman, arranged the match for social advancement, not love. Then there is the matter of the mysterious gentleman seen speaking with her before the ceremony—a man later identified as Mr. Francis Hay Moulton, a former flame from her days in America.”  

Lestrade scoffed. “Moulton was questioned and cleared. He had an alibi for the time of the disappearance.”  

“An alibi provided by his own servants—hardly impartial witnesses. But no matter. The true key lies in the letter.”  

“What letter?”  

Holmes drew a folded sheet of notepaper from his pocket. “This was slipped beneath my door this morning, posted from Paris. It reads: *‘My dear Mr. Holmes, Forgive the subterfuge, but desperate circumstances demanded it. I could not endure the prospect of a loveless marriage, nor the scandal of breaking the engagement openly. By disappearing, I have spared my family humiliation and freed myself. Please assure Lord St. Simon that I bear him no ill will, but I have chosen my own path. Yours sincerely, Hatty Doran.’*”  

Lestrade’s mouth worked soundlessly for a moment. “You mean to say she staged her own disappearance? But the gloves—the ring—”  

“Planted, Inspector. The gloves were old, the ring a cheap imitation. The ‘drowned’ bride was a ruse to divert suspicion toward tragedy rather than desertion. Meanwhile, she and Moulton have undoubtedly reunited and are now living quite happily abroad.”  

Lestrade’s face darkened. “Then she’s made fools of us all—the Yard, the press, even her own family!”  

Holmes chuckled. “Not fools, Lestrade. Merely players in a drama of her own devising. And really, can you blame her? Society’s expectations are a gilded cage for women of her station. She sought freedom, and in her own way, she has achieved it.”  

The inspector exhaled sharply. “Well, I suppose there’s no crime in running away from a marriage. But the resources wasted on this wild goose chase—”  

“Ah, but think of the alternative,” Holmes murmured. “Had she not vanished so dramatically, the scandal would have ruined her reputation regardless. This way, she retains sympathy—the poor, tragic bride lost too soon—while quietly building a new life.”  

Lestrade shook his head. “You’re too clever by half, Holmes. I’ll have to verify this letter, of course, but if it’s genuine…”  

“It is. The stationery is French, the handwriting matches samples from her personal correspondence, and the postmark confirms she is already far from London. The case, Inspector, is closed.”  

With a grunt of reluctant admiration, Lestrade tipped his hat. “Until the next one, then.”  

As the door shut behind him, I turned to Holmes. “You knew all along, didn’t you?”  

He smiled enigmatically. “Not all along, Watson. But the signs were there for one who knew how to look. The absence of any real struggle, the convenient placement of ‘clues,’ the fact that no one actually saw her enter the water… It was a performance, my dear fellow, and a rather brilliant one at that.”  

I shook my head in amazement. “Then Lady St. Simon is not a victim, but a mastermind.”  

Holmes stretched out in his chair, steepling his fingers. “Precisely. And though the world may never know the truth, we may at least take satisfaction in having unraveled her scheme.”  

“And Lord St. Simon?”  

“Will recover in time. He is a proud man, but not a cruel one. Better a temporary humiliation than a lifetime of mutual misery.”  

I considered this, then chuckled. “Holmes, I do believe you’ve gone soft. Defending a runaway bride?”  

“Not soft, Watson. Just.” He reached for his violin, plucking a thoughtful note. “And after all, is it not the role of the detective to uncover truth—even when the truth is kinder than the lie?”  

As the strains of a melancholy melody filled the room, I reflected on the strange twists of human nature. Some crimes were acts of desperation, others of cunning. And sometimes, the greatest mystery was not *what* had happened, but *why*.  

In the case of Lady St. Simon, the answer was simple: freedom. And who were we to deny her that?  

### **Epilogue: Three Months Later**  
A brief notice appeared in the society pages of *The Times*:  

> *Lord St. Simon has withdrawn from public life following the tragic loss of his bride. Meanwhile, in a quiet ceremony in Nice, Mr. Francis Hay Moulton wedded an American lady bearing a striking resemblance to the late Lady St. Simon. The couple has since departed for Argentina.*  

Holmes, upon reading it, merely smiled and tossed the paper aside. “As I said, Watson—the truth is often far more interesting than the fiction.”  

And with that, the curtain fell on one of the most peculiar cases of his career.

Lord St. Simon had by no means relaxed his rigid attitude, but had listened with a frowning brow and a compressed lip to this long narrative.
“Excuse me,” he said, “but it is not my custom to discuss my most intimate personal affairs in this public manner.”
“Then you won’t forgive me? You won’t shake hands before I go?”
“Oh, certainly, if it would give you any pleasure.” He put out his hand and coldly grasped that which she extended to him.
“I had hoped,” suggested Holmes, “that you would have joined us in a friendly supper.”
“I think that there you ask a little too much,” responded his Lordship. “I may be forced to acquiesce in these recent developments, but I can hardly be expected to make merry over them. I think that with your permission I will now wish you all a very good-night.” He included us all in a sweeping bow and stalked out of the room.
“Then I trust that you at least will honour me with your company,” said Sherlock Holmes. “It is always a joy to meet an American, Mr. Moulton, for I am one of those who believe that the folly of a monarch and the blundering of a minister in far-gone years will not prevent our children from being some day citizens of the same world-wide country under a flag which shall be a quartering of the Union Jack with the Stars and Stripes.”
“The case has been an interesting one,” remarked Holmes when our visitors had left us, “because it serves to show very clearly how simple the explanation may be of an affair which at first sight seems to be almost inexplicable. Nothing could be more natural than the sequence of events as narrated by this lady, and nothing stranger than the result when viewed, for instance, by Mr. Lestrade of Scotland Yard.”
“You were not yourself at fault at all, then?”
“From the first, two facts were very obvious to me, the one that the lady had been quite willing to undergo the wedding ceremony, the other that she had repented of it within a few minutes of returning home. Obviously something had occurred during the morning, then, to cause her to change her mind. What could that something be? She could not have spoken to anyone when she was out, for she had been in the company of the bridegroom. Had she seen someone, then? If she had, it must be someone from America because she had spent so short a time in this country that she could hardly have allowed anyone to acquire so deep an influence over her that the mere sight of him would induce her to change her plans so completely. You see we have already arrived, by a process of exclusion, at the idea that she might have seen an American. Then who could this American be, and why should he possess so much influence over her? It might be a lover; it might be a husband. Her young womanhood had, I knew, been spent in rough scenes and under strange conditions. So far I had got before I ever heard Lord St. Simon’s narrative. When he told us of a man in a pew, of the change in the bride’s manner, of so transparent a device for obtaining a note as the dropping of a bouquet, of her resort to her confidential maid, and of her very significant allusion to claim-jumping—which in miners’ parlance means taking possession of that which another person has a prior claim to—the whole situation became absolutely clear. She had gone off with a man, and the man was either a lover or was a previous husband—the chances being in favour of the latter.”
“And how in the world did you find them?”
“It might have been difficult, but friend Lestrade held information in his hands the value of which he did not himself know. The initials were, of course, of the highest importance, but more valuable still was it to know that within a week he had settled his bill at one of the most select London hotels.”
“How did you deduce the select?”
“By the select prices. Eight shillings for a bed and eightpence for a glass of sherry pointed to one of the most expensive hotels. There are not many in London which charge at that rate. In the second one which I visited in Northumberland Avenue, I learned by an inspection of the book that Francis H. Moulton, an American gentleman, had left only the day before, and on looking over the entries against him, I came upon the very items which I had seen in the duplicate bill. His letters were to be forwarded to 226 Gordon Square; so thither I travelled, and being fortunate enough to find the loving couple at home, I ventured to give them some paternal advice and to point out to them that it would be better in every way that they should make their position a little clearer both to the general public and to Lord St. Simon in particular. I invited them to meet him here, and, as you see, I made him keep the appointment.”
“But with no very good result,” I remarked. “His conduct was certainly not very gracious.”
“Ah, Watson,” said Holmes, smiling, “perhaps you would not be very gracious either, if, after all the trouble of wooing and wedding, you found yourself deprived in an instant of wife and of fortune. I think that we may judge Lord St. Simon very mercifully and thank our stars that we are never likely to find ourselves in the same position. Draw your chair up and hand me my violin, for the only problem we have still to solve is how to while away these bleak autumnal evenings.”

When Holmes had finished, the nobleman remained silent for several moments, his fingers drumming impatiently upon the arm of his chair. At last, he spoke, his voice cold and measured.  

“Mr. Holmes,” he said, “I fail to see how this extraordinary tale of yours has any bearing upon the disappearance of my wife. You speak of a man named Francis Hay Moulton, of a marriage in America, of a supposed death—yet none of this explains why Lady St. Simon vanished from her own wedding breakfast.”  

Holmes leaned forward, his keen eyes fixed upon the nobleman’s face. “My dear Lord St. Simon,” he replied, “it explains everything. You have been the victim of a cruel deception—though not, I think, one intended to wound you personally.”  

The nobleman’s frown deepened. “I demand an explanation, sir. If you possess knowledge of my wife’s whereabouts, it is your duty to disclose it at once.”  

“Very well,” said Holmes. “The lady you married was, in fact, already the wife of Francis Hay Moulton. Their marriage in America was perfectly legal, and though he was reported dead, the news was false. He survived, and upon learning of her engagement to you, he hastened to England to reclaim her.”  

Lord St. Simon’s face darkened. “Are you suggesting that my wife deliberately deceived me?”  

“Not deliberately, no,” said Holmes. “She believed herself a widow. When Moulton reappeared, she was faced with an impossible choice—between her lawful husband and the man to whom she had just pledged herself in marriage. She chose the former, as any honorable woman would.”  

The nobleman rose abruptly from his chair, his aristocratic composure slipping for the first time. “This is intolerable!” he exclaimed. “Do you mean to tell me that my marriage is invalid?”  

“I fear so,” said Holmes. “The ceremony was conducted under a misapprehension. Lady St. Simon—or rather, Mrs. Moulton—was not free to marry you.”  

For a moment, Lord St. Simon stood rigid, his hands clenched at his sides. Then, with a visible effort, he mastered himself. “And where is she now?” he asked in a voice of icy calm.  

“She and Mr. Moulton have left England,” Holmes replied. “They wished to avoid scandal—for your sake as much as their own.”  

The nobleman gave a bitter laugh. “How very considerate of them.” He turned toward the door, then paused. “Mr. Holmes, I trust you will exercise discretion in this matter. The reputation of my family—”  

“Is safe with me,” Holmes assured him. “No word of this shall pass beyond these walls unless you yourself choose to make it public.”  

Lord St. Simon inclined his head stiffly. “I am obliged to you.” With that, he strode from the room, his pride wounded but his dignity intact.  

Watson, who had listened in silence to the entire exchange, let out a low whistle. “A most unhappy affair, Holmes,” he remarked.  

“Indeed,” said Holmes, reaching for his pipe. “But not an uncommon one. The heart, my dear Watson, is a singularly unpredictable organ. It obeys no laws—not even those of matrimony.”  

Watson shook his head. “Still, one cannot help feeling some sympathy for Lord St. Simon. To be humiliated in such a fashion—”  

“Ah, but consider the alternative,” Holmes interrupted. “Had the truth not come to light, he might have spent years in a marriage founded upon a lie. As it is, he is free to seek a wife who can give him her whole heart—not one divided by past attachments.”  

Watson considered this. “I suppose you are right. And yet, the lady’s conduct—to vanish without a word—”  

“Was undoubtedly distressing,” Holmes conceded. “But remember, Watson, she was caught between duty and desire. She chose the path of honor, though it cost her dearly. One cannot fault her for that.”  

As Holmes lit his pipe and settled back into his chair, Watson reflected upon the strange twists of fate that had brought them this case. It was, he thought, a sobering reminder that even the most carefully laid plans could be undone by the complexities of human emotion.  

“Well,” he said at last, “I daresay Lord St. Simon will recover in time. A man of his standing is not likely to remain unmarried for long.”  

Holmes smiled faintly. “No, indeed. And when next he chooses a bride, let us hope she comes without a hidden past.”  

The fire crackled in the grate, casting flickering shadows across the walls of 221B Baker Street. Outside, the sounds of London carried on as usual, indifferent to the private dramas unfolding within its midst. Another case had been solved, another mystery laid to rest—but the echoes of human passion, Watson knew, would linger long after the details had faded into obscurity.  

And with that, Sherlock Holmes closed his eyes, the smoke from his pipe curling lazily upward, as the great detective allowed himself a rare moment of repose.

“Holmes,” said I as I stood one morning in our bow-window looking down the street, “here is a madman coming along. It seems rather sad that his relatives should allow him to come out alone.”
My friend rose lazily from his armchair and stood with his hands in the pockets of his dressing-gown, looking over my shoulder. It was a bright, crisp February morning, and the snow of the day before still lay deep upon the ground, shimmering brightly in the wintry sun. Down the centre of Baker Street it had been ploughed into a brown crumbly band by the traffic, but at either side and on the heaped-up edges of the footpaths it still lay as white as when it fell. The grey pavement had been cleaned and scraped, but was still dangerously slippery, so that there were fewer passengers than usual. Indeed, from the direction of the Metropolitan Station no one was coming save the single gentleman whose eccentric conduct had drawn my attention.
He was a man of about fifty, tall, portly, and imposing, with a massive, strongly marked face and a commanding figure. He was dressed in a sombre yet rich style, in black frock-coat, shining hat, neat brown gaiters, and well-cut pearl-grey trousers. Yet his actions were in absurd contrast to the dignity of his dress and features, for he was running hard, with occasional little springs, such as a weary man gives who is little accustomed to set any tax upon his legs. As he ran he jerked his hands up and down, waggled his head, and writhed his face into the most extraordinary contortions.
“What on earth can be the matter with him?” I asked. “He is looking up at the numbers of the houses.”
“I believe that he is coming here,” said Holmes, rubbing his hands.
“Here?”
“Yes; I rather think he is coming to consult me professionally. I think that I recognise the symptoms. Ha! did I not tell you?” As he spoke, the man, puffing and blowing, rushed at our door and pulled at our bell until the whole house resounded with the clanging.
A few moments later he was in our room, still puffing, still gesticulating, but with so fixed a look of grief and despair in his eyes that our smiles were turned in an instant to horror and pity. For a while he could not get his words out, but swayed his body and plucked at his hair like one who has been driven to the extreme limits of his reason. Then, suddenly springing to his feet, he beat his head against the wall with such force that we both rushed upon him and tore him away to the centre of the room. Sherlock Holmes pushed him down into the easy-chair and, sitting beside him, patted his hand and chatted with him in the easy, soothing tones which he knew so well how to employ.

“You have come to me to tell your story, have you not?” said he. “You are fatigued with your haste. Pray wait until you have recovered yourself, and then I shall be most happy to look into any little problem which you may submit to me.”
The man sat for a minute or more with a heaving chest, fighting against his emotion. Then he passed his handkerchief over his brow, set his lips tight, and turned his face towards us.
“No doubt you think me mad?” said he.
“I see that you have had some great trouble,” responded Holmes.
“God knows I have!—a trouble which is enough to unseat my reason, so sudden and so terrible is it. Public disgrace I might have faced, although I am a man whose character has never yet borne a stain. Private affliction also is the lot of every man; but the two coming together, and in so frightful a form, have been enough to shake my very soul. Besides, it is not I alone. The very noblest in the land may suffer unless some way be found out of this horrible affair.”
“Pray compose yourself, sir,” said Holmes, “and let me have a clear account of who you are and what it is that has befallen you.”
“My name,” answered our visitor, “is probably familiar to your ears. I am Alexander Holder, of the banking firm of Holder & Stevenson, of Threadneedle Street.”
The name was indeed well known to us as belonging to the senior partner in the second largest private banking concern in the City of London. What could have happened, then, to bring one of the foremost citizens of London to this most pitiable pass? We waited, all curiosity, until with another effort he braced himself to tell his story.
“I feel that time is of value,” said he; “that is why I hastened here when the police inspector suggested that I should secure your co-operation. I came to Baker Street by the Underground and hurried from there on foot, for the cabs go slowly through this snow. That is why I was so out of breath, for I am a man who takes very little exercise. I feel better now, and I will put the facts before you as shortly and yet as clearly as I can.
“It is, of course, well known to you that in a successful banking business as much depends upon our being able to find remunerative investments for our funds as upon our increasing our connection and the number of our depositors. One of our most lucrative means of laying out money is in the shape of loans, where the security is unimpeachable. We have done a good deal in this direction during the last few years, and there are many noble families to whom we have advanced large sums upon the security of their pictures, libraries, or plate.
“Yesterday morning I was seated in my office at the bank when a card was brought in to me by one of the clerks. I started when I saw the name, for it was that of none other than—well, perhaps even to you I had better say no more than that it was a name which is a household word all over the earth—one of the highest, noblest, most exalted names in England. I was overwhelmed by the honour and attempted, when he entered, to say so, but he plunged at once into business with the air of a man who wishes to hurry quickly through a disagreeable task.
“‘Mr. Holder,’ said he, ‘I have been informed that you are in the habit of advancing money.’
“‘The firm does so when the security is good.’ I answered.
“‘It is absolutely essential to me,’ said he, ‘that I should have £ 50,000 at once. I could, of course, borrow so trifling a sum ten times over from my friends, but I much prefer to make it a matter of business and to carry out that business myself. In my position you can readily understand that it is unwise to place one’s self under obligations.’
“‘For how long, may I ask, do you want this sum?’ I asked.
“‘Next Monday I have a large sum due to me, and I shall then most certainly repay what you advance, with whatever interest you think it right to charge. But it is very essential to me that the money should be paid at once.’
“‘I should be happy to advance it without further parley from my own private purse,’ said I, ‘were it not that the strain would be rather more than it could bear. If, on the other hand, I am to do it in the name of the firm, then in justice to my partner I must insist that, even in your case, every businesslike precaution should be taken.’
“‘I should much prefer to have it so,’ said he, raising up a square, black morocco case which he had laid beside his chair. ‘You have doubtless heard of the Beryl Coronet?’
“‘One of the most precious public possessions of the empire,’ said I.
“‘Precisely.’ He opened the case, and there, imbedded in soft, flesh-coloured velvet, lay the magnificent piece of jewellery which he had named. ‘There are thirty-nine enormous beryls,’ said he, ‘and the price of the gold chasing is incalculable. The lowest estimate would put the worth of the coronet at double the sum which I have asked. I am prepared to leave it with you as my security.’
“I took the precious case into my hands and looked in some perplexity from it to my illustrious client.
“‘You doubt its value?’ he asked.
“‘Not at all. I only doubt—’
“‘The propriety of my leaving it. You may set your mind at rest about that. I should not dream of doing so were it not absolutely certain that I should be able in four days to reclaim it. It is a pure matter of form. Is the security sufficient?’
“‘Ample.’
“‘You understand, Mr. Holder, that I am giving you a strong proof of the confidence which I have in you, founded upon all that I have heard of you. I rely upon you not only to be discreet and to refrain from all gossip upon the matter but, above all, to preserve this coronet with every possible precaution because I need not say that a great public scandal would be caused if any harm were to befall it. Any injury to it would be almost as serious as its complete loss, for there are no beryls in the world to match these, and it would be impossible to replace them. I leave it with you, however, with every confidence, and I shall call for it in person on Monday morning.’

When I was alone once more, however, with the precious case lying upon the table in front of me, I could not but think with some misgivings of the immense responsibility which it entailed upon me. There could be no doubt that, as it was a national possession, a horrible scandal would ensue if any misfortune should occur to it. I already regretted having ever consented to take charge of it. However, it was too late to alter the matter now, so I locked it up in my private safe and turned once more to my work.
“When evening came I felt that it would be an imprudence to leave so precious a thing in the office behind me. Bankers’ safes had been forced before now, and why should not mine be? I do not know what I could do without her. In only one matter has she ever gone against my wishes. Twice my boy has asked her to marry him, for he loves her devotedly, but each time she has refused him.

“‘For Heaven’s sake, don’t let anyone know that I have been here,’ said he. ‘If it were known, my credit would be gone in an instant.’  

“I assured him of my discretion, and then I asked him upon what security he wished to borrow.  

“‘I will give you the Beryl Coronet,’ said he.  

“‘The Beryl Coronet!’ I gasped.  

“‘You have heard of it?’ said he.  

“‘It is one of the most precious public possessions of the empire,’ said I.  

“‘Precisely,’ said he. ‘It is invaluable. I would not part with it for twice the sum I am asking. But I must have the money at once. I will bring it to you to-morrow, and you shall give me the money then.’  

“I was staggered at the proposal. ‘I am afraid,’ said I, ‘that this is hardly a business transaction.’  

“‘It is the only way in which I can raise the money,’ said he. ‘If you cannot do it, I must try elsewhere.’  

“I thought the matter over. ‘Very well,’ said I at last. ‘I will do it. But I must insist upon one condition.’  

“‘Name it,’ said he.  

“‘That the coronet shall be left with me until you redeem it.’  

“‘That is impossible,’ said he. ‘It would ruin me.’  

“‘Then the matter is at an end,’ said I.  

“He looked at me for a moment in silence. Then—  

“‘Very well,’ said he. ‘I agree to your condition. I will bring the coronet to-morrow, and you shall give me the fifty thousand pounds.’  

“He rose and left me. I locked the coronet in my private safe, and went home to Streatham with my mind full of cares.

“You have come to me to tell your story, have you not?” said he, leaning back in his armchair and fixing his keen, penetrating eyes upon the agitated figure before him. The man hesitated, his fingers nervously twisting the brim of his hat.  

“Yes, Mr. Holmes,” he replied at last, his voice trembling slightly. “I—I hardly know where to begin.”  

Holmes waved a languid hand. “Begin at the beginning,” he suggested. “Facts, my dear sir, nothing but facts. Omit nothing, however trivial it may seem.”  

The visitor drew a deep breath and began.  

“My name is James Mortimer, and I am a doctor by profession. Until recently, I practiced in the small village of Grimpen, on the edge of Dartmoor. It is a lonely place, Mr. Holmes, and the moor itself is a wild and desolate expanse, full of treacherous bogs and eerie legends. But it was not the moor that brought me to you—it was the death of my friend, Sir Charles Baskerville.”  

Holmes’s eyes gleamed with sudden interest. “Ah,” he murmured. “Pray continue.”  

“Sir Charles was a kind and generous man, the last of his ancient line. He had returned from abroad some years ago to take up residence at Baskerville Hall, the family estate. Though he was not a young man, he was in excellent health—or so it seemed. Then, three nights ago, he was found dead on the path leading to the moor. His face was twisted in horror, as though he had seen something unspeakable. The local physician could find no natural cause of death.”  

“And you suspect foul play?” Holmes inquired.  

Mortimer hesitated. “There is more, Mr. Holmes. A legend haunts the Baskerville family—a curse, if you will. It is said that centuries ago, a wicked ancestor, Sir Hugo Baskerville, was hunted down and killed by a monstrous hound, a creature of hell itself. Ever since, the hound has been said to stalk the moors, preying upon the Baskervilles. Sir Charles, though a rational man, had grown increasingly fearful of the legend in the weeks before his death.”  

Holmes steepled his fingers beneath his chin. “A most intriguing case,” he mused. “But tell me, Dr. Mortimer, what evidence leads you to believe that Sir Charles’s death was not the result of natural causes?”  

Mortimer reached into his pocket and produced a yellowed manuscript. “This is an old family document detailing the legend. But more importantly, I found these near Sir Charles’s body.” He unfolded a handkerchief to reveal several large paw prints, pressed into the soft earth.  

Holmes examined them closely. “Hound’s prints,” he murmured. “And of an extraordinary size.”  

“Exactly,” Mortimer said grimly. “And there is one more thing. Sir Charles’s heir, his nephew Sir Henry Baskerville, is due to arrive from Canada tomorrow to take possession of the estate. I fear for his life, Mr. Holmes. If the curse is real—”  

“There are no curses, Dr. Mortimer,” Holmes interrupted sharply. “Only men who exploit superstition for their own ends. But I agree that the circumstances are suspicious. Very well—I shall look into the matter.”  

Mortimer’s relief was palpable. “Thank you, Mr. Holmes! But what must we do?”  

Holmes rose and paced the room, his mind already racing ahead. “First, we must meet Sir Henry and ensure his safety. Then, I shall accompany you to Dartmoor to investigate the scene of Sir Charles’s death. In the meantime, say nothing of your visit to me. Let the killer—if killer there be—believe his work has gone unnoticed.”  

Mortimer nodded eagerly. “You will come to Devonshire, then?”  

“Most assuredly,” Holmes replied. “And I shall bring Dr. Watson with me. His steady nerves and military training may prove invaluable.”  

As Mortimer took his leave, Holmes turned to me with a rare smile. “Well, Watson, what do you make of it?”  

I shook my head in bewilderment. “It sounds like something out of a Gothic novel, Holmes. A spectral hound haunting a family—surely it’s nonsense!”  

“Perhaps,” Holmes said thoughtfully. “But where there is smoke, there is often fire. And I have learned never to dismiss a case until all the facts are laid bare.”  

Little did I know then that our journey to Dartmoor would plunge us into one of the most sinister and dangerous adventures of our careers—one that would test not only Holmes’s deductive powers but our very courage in the face of the unknown.  

The next morning, we met Sir Henry Baskerville at his hotel—a robust, plain-spoken man with the bearing of one accustomed to the rugged life of the colonies. He greeted us warmly, though his eyes betrayed a lurking unease.  

“Dr. Mortimer has told me of your concerns,” Holmes said without preamble. “I must ask, Sir Henry—have you noticed anything unusual since your arrival in England?”  

Sir Henry frowned. “Now that you mention it, yes. Yesterday, I received this.” He handed Holmes a letter, composed of words cut from a newspaper. It read:  

*“As you value your life, keep away from the moor.”*  

Holmes examined it closely. “The postmark is from London. Someone is watching you, Sir Henry.”  

“But who?” the baronet demanded. “And why?”  

“That,” Holmes said grimly, “is what we intend to discover.”  

And so our investigation began—an investigation that would lead us through the fog-shrouded moors, into the heart of a centuries-old mystery, and face-to-face with a terror that defied all rational explanation.  

But that, as they say, is another story.

detailed_summary: Holder shares his account of the previous evening.
After dinner, he informed Arthur and Mary about the valuable treasure (the coronet) under their roof, omitting the client's name. Lucy Parr, the maid, might have overheard before leaving the room.
Arthur expressed interest and casually remarked on the bureau's insecure lock, which Holder dismissed.
Later, Arthur gravely asked Holder for £200 to settle club debts.
Holder angrily refused, leading Arthur to state he must find other means to avoid dishonour.
After Arthur left, Holder checked the coronet was safe in the bureau.
Performing a house security check, Holder saw Mary closing and fastening the hall side window.
Mary reported seeing Lucy Parr slip in the back door, suggesting she'd met someone outside and that it should be stopped.
Holder agreed to address it and retired to bed after Mary assured him all was secure.
Around 2 AM, Holder was woken by a sound like a window closing gently.
He then heard distinct footsteps in the adjoining dressing-room.
Peeking in, he saw Arthur, partially dressed, holding the coronet and appearing to wrench it.
Holder cried out, accusing Arthur of theft.
Arthur dropped the coronet, looking deathly pale. Holder examined it and found a corner with three beryls missing.
Holder furiously accused Arthur of destroying the coronet and stealing the jewels.
Arthur denied theft and refused further discussion due to Holder's insults, declaring he would leave the house.
Holder threatened police involvement; the commotion roused the household.
Mary rushed in, saw the scene, screamed, and fainted.
Holder summoned the police.
When the police arrived, Arthur sullenly asked if Holder intended to charge him.
Holder declared it a public matter concerning national property.
Arthur requested five minutes outside before arrest, which Holder denied, suspecting he meant to escape or hide the gems.
Holder pleaded with Arthur to reveal the gems' location to avoid national scandal, offering forgiveness.
Arthur contemptuously refused.
Holder instructed the inspector to arrest Arthur.
An immediate search of Arthur, his room, and the house yielded no trace of the missing gems.
Arthur remained silent despite pleas and threats.
The following morning, Arthur was taken to a cell, and Holder rushed to Holmes, confessing the police were baffled and offering a £1000 reward.
Holder concludes his story in despair, rocking back and forth, lamenting the loss of honour, gems, and son.

“Now, Mr. Holmes, you know the people who live under my roof, and I shall continue with my miserable story.
“When we were taking coffee in the drawing-room that night after dinner, I told Arthur and Mary my experience, and of the precious treasure which we had under our roof, suppressing only the name of my client. Lucy Parr, who had brought in the coffee, had, I am sure, left the room; but I cannot swear that the door was closed. Mary and Arthur were much interested and wished to see the famous coronet, but I thought it better not to disturb it.
“‘Where have you put it?’ asked Arthur.
“‘In my own bureau.’
“‘Well, I hope to goodness the house won’t be burgled during the night.’ said he.
“‘It is locked up,’ I answered.
“‘Oh, any old key will fit that bureau. When I was a youngster I have opened it myself with the key of the box-room cupboard.’
“He often had a wild way of talking, so that I thought little of what he said. He followed me to my room, however, that night with a very grave face.
“‘Look here, dad,’ said he with his eyes cast down, ‘can you let me have £ 200?’
“‘No, I cannot!’ I answered sharply. ‘I have been far too generous with you in money matters.’
“‘You have been very kind,’ said he, ‘but I must have this money, or else I can never show my face inside the club again.’
“‘And a very good thing, too!’ I cried.
“‘Yes, but you would not have me leave it a dishonoured man,’ said he. ‘I could not bear the disgrace. I must raise the money in some way, and if you will not let me have it, then I must try other means.’
“I was very angry, for this was the third demand during the month. ‘You shall not have a farthing from me,’ I cried, on which he bowed and left the room without another word.
“When he was gone I unlocked my bureau, made sure that my treasure was safe, and locked it again. Then I started to go round the house to see that all was secure—a duty which I usually leave to Mary but which I thought it well to perform myself that night. As I came down the stairs I saw Mary herself at the side window of the hall, which she closed and fastened as I approached.
“‘Tell me, dad,’ said she, looking, I thought, a little disturbed, ‘did you give Lucy, the maid, leave to go out to-night?’
“‘Certainly not.’
“‘She came in just now by the back door. I have no doubt that she has only been to the side gate to see someone, but I think that it is hardly safe and should be stopped.’
“‘You must speak to her in the morning, or I will if you prefer it. Are you sure that everything is fastened?’
“‘Quite sure, dad.’
“‘Then, good-night.’ I kissed her and went up to my bedroom again, where I was soon asleep.
“I am endeavouring to tell you everything, Mr. Holmes, which may have any bearing upon the case, but I beg that you will question me upon any point which I do not make clear.”
“On the contrary, your statement is singularly lucid.”
“I come to a part of my story now in which I should wish to be particularly so. I am not a very heavy sleeper, and the anxiety in my mind tended, no doubt, to make me even less so than usual. About two in the morning, then, I was awakened by some sound in the house. It had ceased ere I was wide awake, but it had left an impression behind it as though a window had gently closed somewhere. I lay listening with all my ears. Suddenly, to my horror, there was a distinct sound of footsteps moving softly in the next room. I slipped out of bed, all palpitating with fear, and peeped round the corner of my dressing-room door.
“‘Arthur!’ I screamed, ‘you villain! you thief! How dare you touch that coronet?’
“The gas was half up, as I had left it, and my unhappy boy, dressed only in his shirt and trousers, was standing beside the light, holding the coronet in his hands. He appeared to be wrenching at it, or bending it with all his strength. At my cry he dropped it from his grasp and turned as pale as death. I snatched it up and examined it. One of the gold corners, with three of the beryls in it, was missing.
“‘You blackguard!’ I shouted, beside myself with rage. ‘You have destroyed it! You have dishonoured me forever! Where are the jewels which you have stolen?’
“‘Stolen!’ he cried.
“‘Yes, thief!’ I roared, shaking him by the shoulder.
“‘There are none missing. There cannot be any missing,’ said he.
“‘There are three missing. And you know where they are. Must I call you a liar as well as a thief? Did I not see you trying to tear off another piece?’
“‘You have called me names enough,’ said he, ‘I will not stand it any longer. I shall not say another word about this business, since you have chosen to insult me. I will leave your house in the morning and make my own way in the world.’
“‘You shall leave it in the hands of the police!’ I cried half-mad with grief and rage. ‘I shall have this matter probed to the bottom.’
“‘You shall learn nothing from me,’ said he with a passion such as I should not have thought was in his nature. ‘If you choose to call the police, let the police find what they can.’
“By this time the whole house was astir, for I had raised my voice in my anger. Mary was the first to rush into my room, and, at the sight of the coronet and of Arthur’s face, she read the whole story and, with a scream, fell down senseless on the ground. I sent the housemaid for the police and put the investigation into their hands at once. When the inspector and a constable entered the house, Arthur, who had stood sullenly with his arms folded, asked me whether it was my intention to charge him with theft. I answered that it had ceased to be a private matter, but had become a public one, since the ruined coronet was national property. I was determined that the law should have its way in everything.
“‘At least,’ said he, ‘you will not have me arrested at once. It would be to your advantage as well as mine if I might leave the house for five minutes.’
“‘That you may get away, or perhaps that you may conceal what you have stolen,’ said I. And then, realising the dreadful position in which I was placed, I implored him to remember that not only my honour but that of one who was far greater than I was at stake; and that he threatened to raise a scandal which would convulse the nation. He might avert it all if he would but tell me what he had done with the three missing stones.
“‘You may as well face the matter,’ said I; ‘you have been caught in the act, and no confession could make your guilt more heinous. If you but make such reparation as is in your power, by telling us where the beryls are, all shall be forgiven and forgotten.’
“‘Keep your forgiveness for those who ask for it,’ he answered, turning away from me with a sneer. I saw that he was too hardened for any words of mine to influence him. There was but one way for it. I called in the inspector and gave him into custody. A search was made at once not only of his person but of his room and of every portion of the house where he could possibly have concealed the gems; but no trace of them could be found, nor would the wretched boy open his mouth for all our persuasions and our threats. This morning he was removed to a cell, and I, after going through all the police formalities, have hurried round to you to implore you to use your skill in unravelling the matter. The police have openly confessed that they can at present make nothing of it. You may go to any expense which you think necessary. I have already offered a reward of £ 1000. My God, what shall I do! I have lost my honour, my gems, and my son in one night. Oh, what shall I do!”
